title: Disproportionate Assets and Revenue Embezzlement Case of Madan Prasad Gupta
description:
Madan Prasad Gupta, a non-gazetted first-class officer (Nayab Subba), was convicted in multiple corruption cases primarily involving the embezzlement of government revenue and the illegal accumulation of disproportionate assets during his tenure at various Land Revenue Offices (LROs). The Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) initiated a major investigation into his activities, culminating in several charges filed at the Special Court in Kathmandu.

The most significant case, filed on November 28, 2019, accused Gupta of amassing wealth illegally. Over his 29-year career, which began around 1990, his total assets were valued at NPR 19,36,00,000. However, his legitimate income from salary and other verifiable sources was calculated to be only NPR 4,54,00,000. The CIAA determined that he had illegally acquired assets worth NPR 14,81,00,000.

Gupta's method of corruption included:

  • Collecting revenue from service seekers at the LRO but depositing only a partial amount into the government treasury, pocketing the difference.
  • Creating fraudulent records to conceal the embezzlement.
  • Abusing his authority to influence decisions on disputed public land in exchange for bribes.
  • Hiding his ill-gotten wealth by registering assets in the names of his wife, Rita Devi, and sons, Vicky Gupta and Rocky Gupta.

On January 23, 2024, a Special Court bench found Madan Prasad Gupta guilty in seven separate corruption cases. He was sentenced to five years in prison. In one of the embezzlement cases, he was also ordered to pay a fine of NPR 4,754,000 and repay the embezzled amount of NPR 9,508,000.
unverified_info:
The following information is based on reports but lacks precise, verifiable details:

  • Start of Service: Madan Prasad Gupta reportedly began his government service as a Kharidar in 2047 BS (circa 1990 AD) at the Land Revenue Office, Mustang.
  • Promotion Date: He was reportedly promoted to Nayab Subba in 2064 BS (circa 2007 AD).
  • Alleged Embezzlement Period: The primary period of embezzlement at LRO Parsa is stated to be between 2064 BS and 2074 BS (c. 2007 - 2017).
  • Discrepancy in Amount: One report mentions the illegally acquired assets as NPR 14,81,00,000, while another initial document cited in the research notes states 14 crore 89 lakh 23 rupees.
  • Additional Implicated Individuals: While cases were filed against them, the specific roles and outcomes for Kavita Kumari, Niraj Kumar Gupta, and Rajesh Kumar Gupta are not detailed in the provided sources.
  • Approximate Case Filing Date: A case accusing Gupta of embezzling approximately Rs 12.5 million was reportedly filed around September 23, 2023.
key_allegations: Illegal acquisition of disproportionate assets valued at over NPR 14.8 crore
Embezzlement of government revenue at Land Revenue Offices
Money laundering by concealing illicit assets in the names of family members
related_entities: Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA)

timeline.title: Revenue Embezzlement at LRO Parsa
timeline.description: Madan Prasad Gupta allegedly embezzled Rs 162,000 from collected revenue over eight days at the Land Revenue Office in Parsa.

timeline.title: CIAA Files Major Disproportionate Assets Case
timeline.description: The CIAA filed a charge sheet at the Special Court against Madan Prasad Gupta for illegally amassing assets worth NPR 14,81,00,000.

timeline.title: CIAA Files Another Corruption Case
timeline.description: The CIAA filed a corruption case against Gupta and three other former employees of the Land Revenue Office, Parsa, including the office chief.

timeline.title: Special Court Convicts and Sentences Gupta
timeline.description: A Special Court bench sentenced Madan Prasad Gupta to five years in prison after finding him guilty in seven corruption cases. He was also fined and ordered to repay embezzled funds.
